awd_titl_txt: The Effects of the World War II Research Effort on Postwar U.S. Science, Technology, and Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
There is widespread recognition that World War II was a sea-change event in government-science relations and in science and technology policy. The wartime research effort organized under the Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD) and led by Vannevar Bush, increased government investment in science by one to two orders of magnitude. OSRD research contributed to advances in a range of technologies that were crucial for winning the war—from weapons and optics to new medical treatments (such as antimalarials, vaccines, and other therapies that helped limit U.S. solider morbidity and mortality). In addition to laying the groundwork for postwar U.S. science and technology policy, the wartime effort is also thought to have had a transformative impact on the U.S. innovation system, including by catapulting U.S. firms and universities to the frontier of science and technology for the postwar period. As the war ended, President Roosevelt asked Bush to draw lessons from this "unique experiment" to harness science in peacetime. Bush’s response, Science: The Endless Frontier, is sometimes considered the ideological blueprint for postwar science policy. 

The goal of this project is to provide a quantitative assessment of the effects of the OSRD. Using newly-collected data on OSRD research contracts, this project examines (i) the effects of the wartime research effort on the intensity, direction, and location of postwar U.S. inventive activity, (ii) the influence of wartime medical research spending on postwar U.S. research, patenting, and product development in the life sciences, and (iii) the effects of the OSRD on the postwar U.S. scientific workforce. The use of novel datasets and methodological robust techniques for analyzing heterogeneous historical data will inform several other fields of study and serve as a rich training ground for students. Furthermore, the year 2020 marks the 75th anniversary of Science: the Endless Frontier. This project will provide a roadmap for ensuring US competitiveness and strength in the innovation system, particularly in times of exogenous shock.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the organization of the U.S. World War II research effort, and its impact on the U.S. innovation system. During the war the newly-created Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD) funded and coordinated an expansive effort to advance technologies and medical therapies addressing wartime problems. This was by many accounts the largest single policy shock in the history of the U.S. innovation system, representing the U.S. federal government's first significant investment in extramural research & development (R&D), and was a turning point in the development of national R&D policy.

Despite its place in the history of U.S. innovation policy, OSRD has received limited attention in modern policy, scholarship, and commentary. Our project made two contributions. A first was to understand and document how OSRD managed to bring dozens of high-impact technologies from bench to battlefield in under five years, and where else might its approach be useful today—an investigation which drew direct links to the Covid-19 innovation effort in the 2020s. Second, provide quantitative evidence on the impact of the OSRD innovation effort on the U.S. innovation system and high-tech economy.

Intellectual Merit

Our principal research outcomes included:

  • A first research paper (Gross and Sampat 2023a) that described how OSRD worked and explored what insights it offers today. We found that several aspects of OSRD continue to be relevant to modern research policy, especially in crises, and also discussed the limits to generalizing from World War II to settings with structurally different R&D problems.
  • A second paper (Gross and Sampat 2023b) found that OSRD permanently shifted the direction of U.S. innovation and catalyzed regional technology hubs around the country. We further determined that these effects were the result of self-reinforcing agglomerative forces rather than attributable to sustained postwar federal R&D investment continuing OSRD's legacy.
  • Continuing research examines (i) biomedical innovation, and (ii) high-tech industrial development, in two separate papers.

Additional research supported by this grant has examined the history of U.S. government patent policy since the war (Sampat 2020, 2021) and the impact of USPTO's power of compulsory secrecy (Gross 2023). The Covid-19 pandemic in 2020 (the first year of this grant) motivated an extension of this project to examine the distinctive features of crisis innovation and innovation policy, and to compare World War II to the Covid-19 response (Gross and Sampat 2021).

Broader impacts

In addition to publications in top academic outlets in economics (American Economic Review), management (Management Science), and innovation studies (Research Policy), we aimed to have broader impact through writing at the boundary of the economics of innovation and policy (e.g., Gross and Sampat 2022) and communication with policymakers and journalists. Collectively, our papers received over a dozen instances of public media coverage; multiple references in think tank reports; citations in the 2023 and 2024 Economic Report of the President; and presentations to specific policy audiences, including in the Department of Defense, at the United Nations, and multiple policy conferences.

As another part of our broader impact effort, we organized a panel "The Past and Future of Innovation Policy: The Bush Report at 75 Years" at the Association for Public Policy Analysis and Management (APPAM) Annual Conference in November 2020, revisiting the legacy of World War II and Vannevar Bush's "blueprint" for science policy (Science, The Endless Frontier), written near the war's end.

We also aimed to have broader impact through the publication of new, public datasets on (i) OSRD R&D investments (Gross and Sampat 2023c) and government-funded patents over the past century (Gross and Sampat 2024). The grant also supported training of four students.

References

Gross, Daniel P. 2023. "The Hidden Costs of Securing Innovation: The Manifold Impacts of Compulsory Invention Secrecy." Management Science, v.69.

Gross, Daniel P. and Sampat, Bhaven N. 2021. "The Economics of Crisis Innovation Policy: A Historical Perspective." AEA Papers and Proceedings, v.111.

Gross, Daniel P. and Sampat, Bhaven N. 2022. "Crisis Innovation Policy from World War II to COVID-19." Entrepreneurship and Innovation Policy and the Economy, v.1.

Gross, Daniel P. and Sampat, Bhaven N. 2023a. "America, Jump-Started: World War II R&D and the Takeoff of the US Innovation System." American Economic Review, v.113.

Gross, Daniel P. and Sampat, Bhaven N. 2023b. "The World War II crisis innovation model: What was it, and where does it apply?" Research Policy, v.52.

Gross, Daniel P. and Sampat, Bhaven N. 2023c. Data from the U.S. Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD) in World War II. Harvard Dataverse, DOI: 10.7910/DVN/POO1ZH.

Gross, Daniel P. and Sampat, Bhaven N. 2024. The Government Patent Register: Data and Documentation. Harvard Dataverse, DOI: 10.7910/DVN/BDCCN9.

Sampat, Bhaven N. 2020. "Whose Drugs Are These?" Issues in Science and Technology, v.36.

Sampat, Bhaven N. 2021. "The Government and Pharmaceutical Innovation: Looking Back and Looking Ahead." Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics, v.49.
